STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 15, 2025
Lauryn Ritchie
Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
615 W. Lovell,
Kalamazoo, MI, 49007
Re: License #: CI390403045
SI #: 2025SIC0000512
Dear Lauryn Ritchie:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of the exit conference, must be completed and routed in CWLM, and must
include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000512
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 31, 2025
License #: CI390403045
Licensee Group Organization: Let's Talk About It CMH Services, PLLC
Licensee Designee: Tonya Moore
Chief Administrator: Lauryn Ritchie
Agency Name: Let's Talk About it Girl's Home III
Agency Address: 615 W. Lovell
Kalamazoo, MI 49007
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2026
Capacity: 14
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
4/18/2025 2:02 PM Face to Face Announced Visit; Interview
4/18/2025 10:13 AM Phone Interview
4/15/2025 4:30 PM Email Documentation received or sent
4/11/2025 11:03 AM Phone Interview
3/31/2025 4:15 PM Email Incident Notification
3/31/2025 4:00 PM Phone Interview
3/31/2025 9:00 AM Onsite Inspection Unannounced Visit; Special
Investigation Initiation
1

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth with multiple mental health diagnoses was not given a
dose of medication as required. The youth was taken to the
hospital to be examined.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Youth A was interviewed via phone on 4/18/25. Youth A
reported she takes medications in the morning and in the evening.
Youth A reported she does not know how many medications she
takes and isn’t very familiar with the medications she takes. Youth
A reported she has always taken medications in front of staff, and
they must be in front of a camera. Youth A reported she has never
missed her medications unless she is in the hospital, and she has
never been given too many medications to her knowledge. Youth
A reported she has not had any concerns with how staff at the
facility dispense her medications.
Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 4/10/25. LD reported she did not have any further
information about the allegations.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed via phone on
3/31/25 and face to face at the facility on 4/10/25. CA reported
Youth A’s medications come pre-separated into a sealed
medication packet, and they receive a new medication pack each
Wednesday. CA reported Youth A has four packets of medications
for each day of the week. One packet of medications is provided
to Youth A in the morning and three packets of medications are
provided to Youth A in the evening before bedtime. When Staff 3
gave Youth A her morning medications on Friday 3/28/25, Staff 3
identified some of Youth A’s medications were missing (all for
Wednesday 3/26/25, one for Friday 3/28/25 evening, and two for
Saturday 3/29/25 – one morning & one evening). In addition, two
of the Thursday evening packets were still present despite Staff 1
signing off that Youth A received all her evening medications on
Thursday 3/27/25. CA reported she watched the camera footage
from the office to try and determine what might have happened to
the medications, but she could not determine anything from the
footage. CA reported she watched Supervisor put the medications
away in the staff office on Wednesday evening around 5:00pm,
2

Staff 2 get out Youth A’s medication packet for the Thursday
morning medication pass, Staff 1 get out the medication packet for
the Thursday evening medication pass, and Staff 3 get out the
medication packet for the Friday morning medication pass. CA
reported no other staff touched the medications according to the
camera footage. CA reported since they didn’t know if Youth A
was provided with too many medications or if the medications
were missing for another reason, they wanted to err on the side of
caution and took her to the hospital to get medically cleared. CA
reported the hospital couldn’t draw blood to identify if Youth A had
an increased level of medications in her system, but Youth A’s
vitals were taken at the facility as well at the hospital, which were
both fine. Youth A returned to the facility after she was medically
cleared. CA reported Youth A had her routine bloodwork
completed on 3/31/25 and there were no concerns noted. CA
reported Youth A’s bloodwork always comes back “abnormal”, but
the doctor and pharmacy do not have any concerns with her
results.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/10/25.
Staff 1 reported on the evening of Thursday, 3/27/25, she cleaned
the kitchen, and then at around 8:50 pm, she passed evening
medications to Youth A and Youth B. Staff 1 reported she
prepared and passed Youth B’s medications first. Staff 1 reported
she went back into the staff office, took out Youth A’s medications,
and made sure the medications on Youth A’s medication list
corresponded with the medication packet. Staff 1 reported she
went out to the living room where Youth A was sitting on the
couch, punched out the three evening packets of medication into
Youth A’s hands, watched Youth A take them with water, and then
did a mouth check to ensure Youth A swallowed the medications.
Staff 1 reported after she passed Youth A’s medications, she then
signed off that she passed Youth A’s medications. Staff 1 reported
the medication log includes a medication sheet with medications
listed separately in different boxes. The morning medications are
highlighted in yellow, and the evening medications are highlighted
in blue. Staff 1 reported staff initial each row/column for the
corresponding medications and day they passed. Staff 1 reported
she feels she knows for sure she punched out the correct
medications for Youth A. Staff 1 described the three evening
medication packets Youth A takes in the evening (one packet has
small pills, the second packet has one large pill, and the last
packet is a lot of different types of pills). Staff 1 reported she
knows for sure she passed the right medications to Youth A
because the large pill in the second packet of the evening
medications fell on the floor when she punched it out for Youth A.
3

Staff 1 reported the pill went a little bit under the couch, so she
picked up the pill off the floor and then gave it to Youth A to take.
Staff 1 reported she couldn’t remember if any of the medications
from Friday 3/28/25 or Saturday 3/29/25 were punched out when
she passed Thursday’s evening medications. Staff 1 could not
explain why the two packets of Youth A’s evening medications
from 3/27/25 were still sealed and in the medication pack. Staff 1
reported she is frustrated because she has been doing this for a
long time and cannot visually remember what Youth A’s
medication pack looked like when she put it back in the
medication safe in the staff office.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 4/11/25. Staff 2 reported
he passed medications to Youth A the morning of Thursday
3/27/25 as he has been her 1:1 staff for a while now. Staff 2
reported when he passed medications, he noticed some
medications were missing out of Youth A’s medication pack, but
he couldn’t remember what specifically was missing. Staff 2 could
not remember if Wednesday 3/26/25 medications were missing or
not. Staff 2 reported he could have taken the initiative to report the
missing medications. However, because Youth A is in and out of
the hospital so often, sometimes her medications are missed for
that reason, so Staff 2 didn’t necessarily see it as odd. Staff 2
reported there needs to be a better process and procedure for
medication passing. Staff 2 reported the pre-sorted medication
packs have been better, but it would still be helpful to have a more
efficient process.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/10/25.
Staff 3 reported she went to pass youth medications on the
morning of Friday, 3/28/25 and she noticed Youth A’s medication
packet had medications missing for times that had not occurred
yet on 3/28/25 and 3/29/25. Staff 3 reported she immediately
stopped passing medications because she didn’t want to
overmedicate Youth A. Staff 3 reported she could not remember if
any other staff passed medications prior to her that morning, but
Youth A didn’t wake up until almost noon, so she knew Youth A
hadn’t received her morning medications yet. Staff 3 reported as
soon as she saw the missing medications, she notified CA.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/10/25. Supervisor reported he picked up Youth A’s medications
from the pharmacy on 3/26/25, brought the medications back to
the facility, labeled the pack with dates, and put them in the
medication cabinet. Supervisor reported he was present when
Staff 1 passed Youth A’s medications to her in the evening of
4

3/27/25, but he didn’t see what medications Staff 1 punched out or
what medications were passed. Supervisor reported he didn’t look
at the medication pack until 3/28/25, when CA showed him the
package where there were missing medications from 3/28/25 and
3/29/25, as well as medications still in the package from the
evening of 3/27/25. Supervisor reported it was decided he and CA
would be the only two individuals responsible for passing
medications until another process could be figured out.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from the evening of 3/27/25 was reviewed. The
video does not have audio. The video shows the living room of the
facility. Youth B is seated on a chaise lounge watching TV.
Supervisor is sitting on the far end of a couch (away from Youth A)
watching TV. Youth A is sitting on another couch in the corner of
the room watching TV. Staff 1 walks into the living room and
stands in front of Youth A. Staff 1 hands Youth A a water bottle
and has a medication pack in her hand. Staff 1 looks at the
medication pack (no details of the medication pack can be seen
on the video). Staff 1 then moves over to the other side of Youth A
with her back facing the camera, which blocks the medication
pack from view of the camera. Staff 1 squats down in front of
Youth A. Supervisor leaves the living room. Due to the camera
angle, the video does not show the medication pack or what
medications Youth A takes. At one point, Staff 1 stands up with
the medication pack in her hand, moves something out of her way,
sits on the couch opposite of Youth A and leans forward.
However, the camera angle prevents the viewer from seeing what
Staff 1 is doing. Staff 1 then stands up, takes a few steps, and
stands in front of Youth A again with the medication pack in her
hand. Supervisor re-enters the living room and sits in the same
spot he was in prior. Staff 1 turns away from Youth A and begins
walking away.
DOCUMENTATION REVIEWED:
• Incident Report dated 3/28/25 authored by CA states Staff
3 notified CA medications appeared to be missing for future
days from Youth A’s bubble pack, and Thursday night’s
medications remained in the bubble pack. Due to the
unknown of whether the medication was missing or
administered to Youth A, vitals were taken at the facility
(which were normal), and Youth A was sent to an
Emergency Room for medical clearance due to the anti-
psychotic Clozaril prescribed to Youth A. Youth A’s blood
levels are checked weekly to monitor the identified anti-
psychotic.
5

• Documentation dated 4/10/25 authored by CA explaining
medications errors states the following medications were
missing from Youth A’s medication packet as of the
morning of Friday 3/28/25:
o Friday 3/28/25 PM – 3.5 pills of Clozaril (350 mg)
o Saturday 3/29/25 AM – Iron Supplement (325 mg),
Multi-Vitamin, Lithium (300 mg), Buspar (10 mg),
Metformin (850 mg), and Levothyroxine Sodium
(Colace).
o Saturday 3/29/25 PM - 3.5 pills of Clozaril (350 mg)
In addition, CA notes 2 out of 3 packets of Youth A’s
3/27/25 PM medications were still sealed and present in
Youth A’s medication pack despite all 3/27/25 PM
medications being signed for by Staff 1.
• Picture still-shot of Youth A’s medication pack on the desk
in the staff office on the evening of 3/27/25 does not clearly
show what medications are present and missing.
• Picture (dated 3/28/25 after AM medication pass) of Youth
A’s medication pack for 3/26/25-4/1/25 shows the following:
o Wednesday 3/26/25 AM med packet is present,
which is accurate as the medication pack was new
as of Wednesday late afternoon/early evening.
o Wednesday 3/26/25 PM meds (3 packets) are
empty, and these medications were passed
appropriately.
o Thursday 3/27/25 AM meds packet is empty, and
these medications were passed appropriately.
o Thursday 3/27/25 PM meds (1st packet) is empty,
and 2 packets were present. These medications
were signed off on by Staff 1, but not passed.
o Friday 3/28/25 AM meds packet is empty, and these
medications were passed appropriately.
o Friday 3/28/25 PM meds (1st packet) is empty, and 2
packets were present. The missing medications
were unaccounted for.
o Saturday 3/29/25 AM meds packet is empty. The
missing medications were unaccounted for.
o Saturday 3/29/25 PM meds (1st packet) is empty,
and 2 packets were present. The missing
medications from the empty packet were
unaccounted for.
o All medications for Sunday 3/30/25-Tuesday 4/1/25
were present.
6

• Picture (dated 4/10/25 during Consultant’s facility visit) of
Youth A’s medication pack for 3/26/25-4/1/25 shows 2 of 3
medication packets for Thursday 3/27/25 PM were still
present and were never passed to Youth A despite being
signed off on by Staff 1.
• Youth A’s Emergency Room discharge paperwork dated
3/28/25 notes Youth A was at her baseline in no acute
distress. Youth A denied any intentional overdose, and
reported she is at a facility where her medications are
monitored. There were no concerns noted.
• Youth A’s bloodwork dated 3/31/25 does not have any
concerns.
• Youth A’s Medication Administration Record from March
2025 notes Staff 1 signed off on providing Youth A with all
her PM medications on 3/27/25.
• Medication Procedure and Guidelines Policy states
medications are in a locked cabinet that cannot be
accessed by youth. Medications are administered to youths
on-site, individually, and are only to be administered by
staff. After medications are administered, a medication
tracking chart is signed by the staff who administered the
medication. Medications not administered due to
medication refusal by youth, or lost/damaged by staff or
youth, are to be documented in an incident report and
reported to the staff’s immediate supervisor. Staff complete
required orientation and training prior to handling,
dispensing, and administering medication. Staff need to
observe seven rights when passing medications (right
individual, right medication, right dose, right time, right
route, right method, right position). If medications are
missing, staff must notify the Chief Administrator. Staff
must document any medication error (incorrect medication
given, no medication in container, no medication given –
oversight, etc.) by completing an incident report form.
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary action in her
employee file. Staff 1 completed Dispensing Medication
training on 7/16/24, 7/18/24 and 7/20/24. Staff 1 completed
and passed a Medication Procedure/Distribution
Competency Test on 7/16/24.
7

Analysis The facility is found in violation as per interviews conducted and
documentation reviewed, Youth A’s medications were not passed
correctly as she was not given all her evening medications on
3/27/25 despite it being documented she was. Although it is not
clear what happened to the missing medications, it is evident,
some of Youth A’s medications from 3/28/25 and 3/29/25 were
punched out of the medication packet prior to the days/times for
those medications occurring.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
May 8, 2025
Shannon (Shay) Mavis Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 15, 2025
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
8
